title: Raspberry Pi 3 Model B
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D-model of a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B.

It can be used for experimenting around with the dimensions and ports of the Raspberry Pi, so you don't need to touch the electronics of the original Raspberry all the time (e.g. if you want to design or build a case).

All case relevant parts should be placed in the correct position according to the mechanical specs of the Raspberry Pi Foundation
https://www.raspberrypi.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/mechanicalspecB+.png

Case relevant are all parts, that might need some cutouts in the case, like the ports, the SD card slot and the SOC's on top and bottom of the PCB:

  • The SOC positions can be relevant if you're using heat sinks.
  • The GPIO has a block form, so that you don't rip off the pins :-)

I made the model with FreeCad and could not print or test it yet - feedback is highly appreciated.

Update 2017-01-14:

Added the stl-file with the ending "Block". This model might be more suitable for 3D printing because it doesn't need any supports (eventually for the audio port). All ports (holes) have been plugged and the bottom has been flattened:

  • the SOC has been replaced by a square hole (so you still know its place)
  • the SD card has been "moved up" to the edge of the PCB

Just remember to add some notional 4mm on the bottom part of the PCB (SOC, SD card, soldering pins, etc.).

Designed using FreeCAD

I designed this model using FreeCAD and according to the mechanical specs of the Raspberry Pi Foundation (https://www.raspberrypi.org/about/):
https://www.raspberrypi.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/mechanicalspecB+.png

This is a Cavern Archway for modular cavern tile system I've mentioned in my other recent creations / remixes.

(Cavern tiles were made of cheap 24x24 inch neoprene workbench floor mats textured with cheap white latex caulk -- see DM Scotty's Tilescapes #14 video on youtube for instructions on how to make these; after texturing I let dry for 2 days and then cut the shapes out before any painting, unlike the way DM Scotty instructs.)

The archway makes the butted up cavern tiles seamless -- and quite good looking. The archway in the rear, was handmade with sculpey. I need many of these and didn't feel like crafting a dozen of them with sculpey -- printing is easier :)

Color scheme:
1) Base: Espresso Brown (very dark brown almost black)
2) Sponge on / Stipple: Americana Burnt Umber
3) Sponge on / stipple sparsely: Americana Burnt Sienna
4) Sponge on / Stipple lightly and all over: Americana Cocoa
5) Dry brush on very light loaded brush, about 50/50 mix of Americana Snow White and Amerciana Cocoa (used in step 4).

EDIT: Mushrooms are made of sculpey and took all of 5 minutes to make like four.. just a few cents worth of Sculpey as well.. bought 2 pounds of Sculpey half off in few months back.. got it for around $7 if I recall. These are my first mushrooms.. planning on crafting many more :)

Any donations appreciated :)

title: Heart Tea Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For my Valentine.

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwIp1mJAwqk

You'll need a tea lamp that is 22mm or less in height, 38mm in diameter.

Designed using Fusion 360, sliced using Cura 2.3.1, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 3 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

See Notes.

Notes:

I printed "Base.stl" at 50% infill using Red PLA.

I printed "Heart.stl" at 100% infill with a brim using Transparent PLA. Printing at less than 100% is fine, you'll just see the infill pattern.

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding may be required.

1) Remove the center support tower from inside "Heart.stl" by snapping it off.

2) Remove the "flame" diffusor from the tea lamp, then press it into "Base.stl".

3) Press "Heart.stl" into "Base.stl".

Hope your Valentine likes it as much as mine!

title: settler catan style interlocking tiles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here you find the interlocking tiles for the magnetic versions of:

  • settlers main game (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1238980)
  • seafarers expansion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393862)
  • cities & knights expansion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1254404)
  • traders & barbarians expansion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:853663)
  • explorers & pirates expansions (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1588996)
  • different scenarios & variants (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1410173)

IMPORTANT BEFORE PRINTING:

  • That the interlocking does work well you have to print those pieces with support. After printing clean out the support structueres nicely. If not the pieces will lift at the sides when connected!
  • If your printer doesn't have a heat bed, this print will hardly work. The interlocking only works if there is no warping of the tiles at all and if they're compleately flat

I also integrated the plain interlocking base in the files. It can be used to glue for example the tiles from JAWong (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26979) on top of it to get an interlocking version of the game.

Just print out the interlocking parts instead of the landscapes of the magnetic versions.

To build up the board, you have to start with the center piece and go around by adding the landscapes.

have fun :-)

BORDERS:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2133068

STORAGE FOR INTERLOCKING TILES: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084410

ALTERNATIVE TILES (by jerry_nz):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2646844 / https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2646848

comments.text: Hello, I am not a Catan player at all, but my sister has been an avid player for years and I want to make a nice set for her (this is going to be a serious labor of love).  Will the tiles in this set still need magnetic bases or can the player fit them all together and play on their own.  I apologize for being dense, but I am trying to surprise her and I do not want to put in the effort and for her not to be able to use it.  I will also take any of your recommedations.  Thank you in advance.
comments.author: DangerAngel

comments.text: Hy, that sounds like a very nice present :-) you don't need any magnets for this version. Just read the description carefully. I would recommend you to print 3 or 4 tiles just to check if your printer-settings work an that the tiles stick together correctly. Important: Print with support and clean out the support nicely. If not, the tiles will probably bend upwards a little bit. If you have any further questions don't hesitate to ask :-)
comments.author: DangerAngel

comments.text: I am test printing right now.  I printed the Interlocking Wood last night and it came out with no problems.  I printed Interlocking Wheat 2 this afternoon and it came out looking like a sponge and was easily crushable with my bare hand ( I have tiny hands too!, Lol) I double checked the settings and there were no differences between the tiles: Both sliced with Cura 2.6.2, both had the same infill, layer height etc.  I am reprinting the Interlocking Wood tile to see if gremlins crawled into my machine while I slept last night.

I am not seeing any issues in layer view but I am very new at this.  I might bump up the wall thickness and see if that makes a difference. But at least the two Woods fit together neatly!  Looking at the bright side.:)

comments.text: Great design! I'm printing these, and probably will be for quite a while, but it will be worth the time. I didn't want to mess with the magnets and add the extra cost, so I've opted for the interlocking tiles. The directions say that you have to start with the center tile, but I was curious how that works with seafarers, where several of the tiles in the middle of the board are left out until later in the game. Do the interlocking pieces still fit in there are the game progresses, or does the board have to be taken apart each time?
comments.author: NJLaPrell

comments.text: Hy one of the disadvantages of those interlocking tiles is, that in the case you describe, the tiles have to be slightly moved to enter a new tile between them. This is just the case if you try to integrate a new tile, which is surrounded by other tiles (more than 3). In this case you have to separate the board a tiny bit to enter the tile. I'm thinking about making a new version for the interlocking tiles that looks more like this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649819. There you wouldn't have this issue, but actually I cant say when it's going to be finished.
comments.author: NJLaPrell

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. Looking forward to any new Catan designs you make in the future. They're great! I've printed enough pieces to play around, and you're right, the separation needed really is just a tiny bit. I think it will work just fine. Thanks again, and thanks for such an awesome design.

remixed_from.title: Monoprice MP Select Mini Filament Guide

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini Filament Guide Remixed

description.text: I originally just wanted to tweak the part I found on Thingiverse but I couldn't get the STL to load in any program. I was greeted with an error that the file was corrupt in each program I tried or the program would just lock up on opening the file. I decided to make a new one from scratch by taking measurements of the original then I used Tinkercad to mock up the design and make my edits. I made the valley deeper and more of a V shape instead of the U shape which made the design easier to print without any supports. I also made the part that curves around the side of the MP Mini a little bigger in diameter to better contour to the corner of the Mini. I created 2 designs in case you need to adjust your bracket there is a standard and slotted screw hole design. I also created a tab to hold the filament in and a few bumps on the upper valley to help with printing.

description.text:
Awesome model of Die Hard's John McClane, played by the famous Bruce WIllis. This model was found on Pinshape for free, and I thought to share it with all of you on Thingiverse. I did not create this model and do not own this model. The model is a cartoon version of John McClane. I painted mine gold and call it the Golden Willis.

Yippie-Ki-Yay, Mother$#@&*%!

Original model location
https://pinshape.com/3d-printed-object/4484-bruce-willis-die-hard

Enjoy!

ANET A6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1000

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Best way to print model is standing up. Add supports manually to arms and chin. Utilized PLA for this print and had minimal defects to correct before post-processing.

Steps to Finish Model
  1. Print Model
  2. Remove supports and rafts from model
  3. Clean model with exacto knife.
  4. Fill holes and areas with epoxy putty
  5. Sand model
  6. Paint model
  7. Take picture of model and post on Thingiverse
  8. Yippie-Ki-Yay, Mother$#@&*%!

title: Judge Dredd Lawgiver Desktop Display
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you are the law, you need to show you are the law.

For display on a desk or shelf, I present the lawgiver from the 2012 movie Dredd.

The entire weapon is only approximately 7 inches long. (Way smaller than the movie prop, but big enough to be mistaken, don't do anything stupid). The special ammo magazine is removable and an insert can be put in its place to cover boy variants of this gun shown in the movie. With the magazine on you can either lock the handle into its slot and display at a raised angle, or allow it to stand up on its own on the display. With the insert in place you use the t_bar on the stand to support it. The Badge sits in its own slot at an angle.

*This is a toy, don't do anything stupid with it.

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha/Flash Forge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 Microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the whole thing without any supports, but I have excellent active cooling, even then the muzzle vents are a bit rough, so you might need supports. I also used a raft with the barrel but that is because of my delta printer, not the model.

Print 2 of the ammo piece

1. Glue the two body pieces together
  2. place an ammo piece in each side of the magazine part
  3. Glue the magazine parts together
  4. Place the magazine or the insert into the space on the body (you might have to sand some for the insert)
  5. Place the t-stand in the base
  6. Place the badge in its slot
  7. place the gun on the display.
I found several pictures from the movie of this gun and modeled it in Fusion 360

Print this container. Fill sodium bicarbonate (1 teaspoon) into the container and insert it into a Kinder Egg toy container. Fill vinegar into the lid of the toy container. Close the toy container carefully without mixing vinegar and sodium bicarbonate. When you are ready to throw the "grenade", give it a really fast shake and throw it.

This is really just for fun. Nothing dangerous. Only a pop. The acid in the vinegar reacts with the sodium bicarbonate and produces carbon dioxide - enough to open the lid of the toy container.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vWyjLh0BB9o

Jurica Pranjic on MyMiniFactory was nice enough to share his rendition of the Titanfall Arc Grenade and when I found it, I decided I needed to have some fun with it. His version is a static prop, so I set about hollowing it out and redesigning it to accept the electronics I had in mind. I sent him a quick message and he was okay with the idea, so I'm sharing the results here.

Each of the eighteen arc 'plugs' has been bored out to accept a 5mm discrete Neopixel LED (or comparable WS2812 LED). The middle of the grenade has been fitted with posts on the interior that snugly slot a 9v battery inside the grenade, with enough extra room for a wire lead connector. The connector in particular I designed this around was a 121-0526/T-GR, but any T-shaped 9v clip should do. I changed the top handle to screw down with four M2 screws onto the body of the grenade so that the 9v could be easily accessed and swapped out.

An arduino (probably a 5v Adafruit Pro Trinket) can be hot-glued to the inside of the grenade, along with a piezo buzzer for sound effects. Two holes were added to the top of the grenade - one for a slide on-off switch, and one for a tactile push-button that will 'arm' the grenade.

The power switch hole is sized to accept an OS102011MS2QN1 slide switch. It does not stick out too much from the top of the grenade, which is fine, because I didn't want it accidentally turning on. The 'Arming' switch is sized for your standard tactile pushbutton.

In discussing this in the comments with others, I've come to suggest that a 5v regulator be added between the battery and the +5V input lines on the neopixels. It is otherwise fairly hard for an arduino to drive so many RGB LEDs at once.

I also added six alignment holes to make sure the grenade halves keyed together properly during assembly.

This code uses Adafruit's NeoPixel library, because it is excellent and does what I am not smart enough to do. If you have not installed this library, make sure you do

// This code was designed to run on an Arduino Pro Mini 5v.

#include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>

#define PIN 2 //Pin used to driving Neopixel Data
#define NUM_PIXELS 18 //Number of neopixels in the arc grenade (1 per plug, 18 plugs)
#define BUTTONPIN 13 //Input button for the 'arming' mechanism.
#define TONEPIN 12 //Output for piezo buzzer to produce audio tones.

//The following is just a few frequencies that correspond with particular musical notes. You can change these to suit whatever tones your particular piezo buzzer is good at procuding.
#define G2 98
#define C3 131
#define C5 523
#define C6 1047
#define E6 1319

long previousMillis = 0;
long previousToneMillis = 0; //separate counter for keeping track of Tone generation.
unsigned long currentMillis = 0;
unsigned long currentToneMillis = 0;
unsigned long lastDebounceTime = 0;
unsigned long debounceDelay = 5;

bool toggleState = false;
const bool armed = true;
const bool disarmed = false;
bool lastState = disarmed;
bool newState = disarmed;
bool justArmed = false;

long lightGenerationInterval = 3; //How often a new flicker effect is created.
long toneGenerationInterval = 70; //How often a new passive audio sound is created.
long fadeInterval = 300;
float fadeTimeValues[NUM_PIXELS];

Adafruit_NeoPixel strip = Adafruit_NeoPixel(NUM_PIXELS, PIN, NEO_GRB + NEO_KHZ800); //If you are getting weird results, check that your neopixels are GRB and not RGB. The discrete through-hole ones (individual) seem to be GRB.

void setup() {
pinMode(BUTTONPIN, INPUT);
strip.begin();
strip.show();
}

void loop() {
buttonRead();
if(toggleState == disarmed){
electricGenerator(); //Function call to create a new 'spark' on a random LED if enough time has passed.
electricUpdate(); //Function call to calculate the decay of spark brightness over time.
playIdleTone(); //Function call to generate passive clicking audio to simulate sparks through Piezo buzzer.
strip.show();
} else {
redFade(50); //"Arming" animation; full red fade to zero.
delay(50);
windUpGrenade(); //Function call to run the scanLine() function multiple times for the appropriate animation.
explode(20); //Kaboom animation.
explode(20);
explode(75);
delay(500);
toggleState = disarmed;
}
}

void windUpGrenade(){
for(int i = 7; i>0; i--){
scanLine(i*3);
}
for(int k=5;k>0;k--){
scanLine(3);
}
}

void buttonRead(){ //Should be some rudimentary amount of debouncing going on here.
newState = digitalRead(BUTTONPIN);
if( lastState != newState ){ //state changed
delay( debounceDelay );
lastState = newState;
if( newState == armed && toggleState == false ){
toggleState = armed;
} else if( newState == armed && toggleState == true ){
toggleState = disarmed;
}
}
}

void playIdleTone(){
currentToneMillis = millis();
if(currentToneMillis - previousToneMillis > toneGenerationInterval){
previousToneMillis = currentToneMillis;
int newTone = random(6);
tone(TONEPIN, C5, 10);
changeToneGenerationInterval();
}
}

void changeToneGenerationInterval(){
toneGenerationInterval = toneGenerationInterval+random(-40,40);
if(toneGenerationInterval > 100){
toneGenerationInterval = 100-random(0,10);
} else if (toneGenerationInterval < 20){
toneGenerationInterval = 20+random(0,10);
}
}

void electricGenerator(){
currentMillis = millis();
if(currentMillis - previousMillis > lightGenerationInterval){
previousMillis = currentMillis;
int newLight = random(NUM_PIXELS);
fadeTimeValues[newLight]=currentMillis; //records the time the new fade starts.
}
}

void electricUpdate(){
for(int i = 0; i<NUM_PIXELS;i++){
int timeSinceNew = currentMillis - fadeTimeValues[i];
if(timeSinceNew>fadeInterval){
strip.setPixelColor(i,0,0,0);
} else {
strip.setPixelColor(i,0,0,easeOutQuad(timeSinceNew, 128, -128, fadeInterval));
}
}
}

void scanLine(float delayValue){
for(int i = 0;i<NUM_PIXELS;i++){
strip.setPixelColor(i,0,255,0);
strip.show();
tone(12, C6+(i*10), 8);
delay(delayValue);
}
for(int y = 0;y<NUM_PIXELS;y++){
strip.setPixelColor(y,0,0,0);
strip.show();
tone(12,G2+(y*10),8);
delay(delayValue);
}
}

void redFade(int steps){
for (int i = 0; i<NUM_PIXELS; i++){
strip.setPixelColor(i,255,255,0);
strip.show();
tone(12, E6, 10);
}
for(int s=0; s<steps; s++){
for(int p=0; p<NUM_PIXELS;p++){
strip.setPixelColor(p,easeOutQuad(s, 180, -180, steps),easeOutQuad(s, 255, -255, steps),0);
}
tone(12, C5+(s*5), 10);
strip.show();
delay(10);
}
}

void explode(int steps){ //Max white brightness out to zero over number of steps. Tone winds up as LEDs wind down.
for (int i = 0; i<NUM_PIXELS; i++){
strip.setPixelColor(i,255,255,255);
}
strip.show();
for(int s=0; s<steps; s++){
for(int p=0; p<NUM_PIXELS;p++){
strip.setPixelColor(p,easeOutQuad(s, 255, -255, steps),easeOutQuad(s, 255, -255, steps),easeOutQuad(s, 255, -255, steps));
}
tone(12, C3+(s*50),10);
strip.show();
delay(10);
}
}

float easeOutQuad (float currentTime, float base, float change, float duration) { //An easing function to make the animations look a little nicer.
currentTime /= duration;
return -change * currentTime*(currentTime-2) + base;
};

comments.text: That one would work fine. It's slightly less efficient than the RECOM ones, but on the scale we're talking it's not that big a deal. Linear regulators like what you've identified there can get a little hot after prolonged use, which is why you see the metal heat sink on the top of the regulator to dissipate heat. The RECOM ones don't need it because they don't waste as much power.
comments.author: asparaguspr

comments.text: Neither the trinket nor the gemma can run the code as I have posted here, because that requires an arduino pro mini or higher board - something with a ATMega328 processor. Gemma and Trinket boards have an ATTiny85 processor, which is incapable of utilizing the tone() functions in the code. That said, you could pare it down to just the light functions and probably get away with it?  You'd need to hook the neopixel 5v line up to a direct power source, rather than the VOut on the gemma, as the gemma can't possibly push enough current out for 18 Neopixels - but it could control the data signal just fine.

title: microSD-card holder for Swatch YIS401G metal wrist and alike

description.text:
Be aware, there's some spy stuff on the table. :)

This is a microSD-card holder which fits into the closure of the metal wrist of a Swatch YIS401G or other watches with the same metal wrist.

There are two parts: The outer part fits into the metal wrist (can be "clicked" in) and must not be pulled out again afterwards. You put the microSD-card into the inner part, and that one fits into the outer part. You can move the inner part a bit, so that you can lock it. The microSD-card stays in place and locks the inner part. You can unlock it by moving the inner part back with some little force applied. If you now shake the watch a bit, the inner part will fall out with no resistance.

Printer:

Dremel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Very high

Infill:

Not as I know

Notes:

It must be very accurate, so choose a high resolution/longer print time.
Should fit exactly, just use the original size.

First I wanted to make a coin like inner part. But this would be to big. Luckily, the "cheap" rectangle part locks itself into the outer part. I did not think about that. Needed some prints until it fitted. Used a + instead of a - on the inner part (for locking/unlocking) because I do not like subtraction. :)
The Swatch YIS401G is not included. ;)

remixed_from.author: DanFineArt
remixed_from.title: MendelMax Y End Idler with Belt Tensioning

description.text:
An updated version of the MendelMax 3d Printer. Nearly every printed part on the bot has been updated to make the assembly easier and faster and the printer more accurate. 
Major upgrades include easier to assemble lower vertexes, Lower mounted Z motor mounts, an improved Y axis belt tensioner system, and easy to align Z axis smooth rod mounts. 
NOTE: While I do not consider this a work in progress, it is still not widely tested. I recommend this design even for new users, but if you prefer a rock solid well tested design you may prefer the original MendelMax.

Full instructions will be published eventually. The Bill of Materials is available at http://goo.gl/x29Kj. Note that except for the bushings, at present it does not include the components for the X carriage or extruder. That BoM is for the kit as supplied by store.mendelmax.com, other variants may require other components. You can also get the full recommended hardware kit or a full printer kit from http://store.mendelmax.com You can download the full STL file set in the first zip file. It is current as of 3/30/2012, but be sure to download any later files separate from the zip file. To see the full model in 3d, download the MendelMax 1.5 PDF file and open with Adobe Acrobat (most 3rd party PDF viewers do not suppport 3d PDF files). The source files are available in the MendelMax 1.5 Alibre files.zip file, and are editable with Alibre CAD.

comments.text: Are there MendelMax 1.5 source files available anywhere?  STL files are a software artifact for distribution, and are not source-code. comments.text: The parts were originally designed to use M5 thin nuts, which are what I recommend. many of the parts allow the use of either nut type, but there are still some that require thin nuts. I will try to  reqork the remaining parts to allow the use of standard M5 soon.

FWIW, the reason I recommend using M5 thin nuts is that they can be used in a pinch as post-insert t-slot nuts (in other words they can be inserted into the slot from the top of the slot instead of the end) so they are a bit more flexible, unfortunately they are harder to find.

comments.text: Another printer smartley moves its Z-Motors to the bottom of the bot.  Well played :)  I am also a fan of driving the Z axis with a single motor, using a belt system to turn both rods at once.
comments.author: idolcrasher

comments.text: A single Z motor adds significant extra complexity (mounting the pulleys ie easy enough, but you also need to design a belt tensioner), and it really doesn't save much cost. By the time you buy three pulleys and a belt you are over $15, so compared to a stepper motor at $20 it is not really compelling.
comments.author: idolcrasher

comments.text: It's not about cost or the complexity of assembly, it's more of a long-term benefit. I've built both a Sells and a Prusa (and now a Max), and the Sells had the only fire-and-forget solution for the Z rods. With two motors, i had to re-synchronize the rods countless times (mostly after trying out higher speeds and having just one motor skip), where the Sells' belt kept everything synchronized.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: Not only do you have to re-sync them occasionally during normal operation; the belt-driven z-axis fails gracefully, whereas two z-axis motors fail miserably.  The belt-driven z-axis has proven to be much more reliable than two motors on the z-axis on every machine we've employed it. It's more efficient, the leadscrews are synced, and it runs faster.  The key is...machine alignment.  Without that - you should just run two motors...
I do see the benefits, but I also see the complexities. I am not saying I will never look at such a design, but for now it is low on my list of priorities.

if your z motors are out of sync, connect them in series instead of parallel. It is easy to make a simple cable adapter that does it and it greatly increases the reliability of them. When in parallel the current won't be evenly split between them unless they have exactly the same resistance which isn't going to happen. By connecting the motors in series the exact same amount of current has to go through both motors coils.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: I have built many MendelMax 1.5's, and I always wire them in series.  But, in my experience, if there is binding on one of the motors, they can still get out of sync.  I fix the binding issue, so they usually don't get out of sync.  Still, its easy for some idiot to grab one of my z-axis motors and turn one of them while the printer is off, un-syncing them..
comments.author: johnmeacham

comments.text: I turn my motors a little here a little there on every single print WHILE the printer is going.  It doesn't hurt it at all, and it helps me get the first layer down perfectly every time.  I just make my adjustments while it's printing the circle around the print.  I use the printerboard with marlin firmware, and when the motors are not actually turning they are powered off, so it feels easy and loose to adjust.  once it is going I never see a problem.

comments.text: I had started my MendelMax 1 before you posted this, so I have 8mm rods and have invested in LM8UUs.  Any chance that you will be able to release stls for X and Z axis items that accomodate 8mm rods and LM8UU bearings?

comments.text: No, I am not a fan of lm8uu's so I doubt I will ever make the effort to convert the parts, though others may do so or you can always mix and match parts with LM8uu poieces from thingiverse (the X ends, X carriage, and Y axis are all compatible with Prusa-compatible parts).
comments.author: paul

comments.text: Okay, straightforward enough.  I do like your Z top and bottom vertices but notice that that they (and the clamps) only accommodate 10mm smooth rods.  Curious, have you found a performance difference between 8mm and 10mm on the z rods?
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: Yes, 10mm has about ~60% more material than 8mm, so it is considerably more rigid.  Because the X axis moves on the Z axis, and because of the high speeds possible on the MendelMax, beefing up the z axis is worthwhile. The difference is small, but the cost difference is negligible.

This is a simple Smartphone Dock for many Smartphones with USB-C or similar
Cable. The Dock holds the Smartphone at a comfortable angle and lets you dock and undock with easy.

It fits all Smartphones which are no more than 12mm thick and no more than 160mm long.

To mount the Cable you need two screws 2-3mm thick and 8-11mm long suitable
for plastic.

The Cable i used is the Roline 11.02.9011 but other Cables might fit as well.

In the Pictures is a Huawei Mate 9

This Print was made on the new Leapfrog Bolt 3D Printer with Black PLA
at a rough 0.20 Layer Height, but it looks and feels good.

Feel free to remix the Model with the attached Source-File for 123D Design.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Remove both Parts from Print-Bed

Move the Cable into the groove within the Stand, position the Cable at an optimal mating hight for the Phone.

Put some Elastic Material or Foam in the Backplate (small Part)

Screw the Backplate with two Plastic screws into the Main Part while making sure
the Cable still has good height so the Phone's Connector can properly mate.

Put the Cable in the Outlet Hole on the Backside of the Stand.

Connect to any USB Port on PC or Charger.

remixed_from.title: Open Source Robotic Arm (Lite Arm i2)

description.text:
EvoArm is a 3+2DOF 3D-printed robotic arm, a new design based in part on the LiteArm i2 design by armatec:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480446

Rather than hobby servos, EvoArm is built to accommodate Dynamixel AX-series smart servos, which feature fairly precise position & speed control and feedback without totally breaking the bank. Most of the bearings used are cheap 608-size skateboard bearings.

The design as provided features a flat end-effector, which is designed to provide tactile/haptic feedback, and which adds an additional 2DOF at the wrist to the base arm's 3DOF.

Full design files and control code: https://github.com/AliShug/EvoArm

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100-200 Micron

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

Parts are sized to fit on the Ultimaker 2 bed. Use brims (or rafts) at your discretion to stop larger pieces from warping, and be aware that a small number of pieces have significant flat overhangs that require supports.

You don't need to print pieces which aren't already exported as STLs! These are composite parts, where several separately printed pieces were designed in one file. The composite parts are broken down into individual IPT files, which depend on the root files, and have been individually exported as STLs.
I'll provide full assembly instructions once I have the chance to build a second arm.

title: USB volume control wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Turn up...

... the volume. This simple project allows you to alter the system volume of your PC, Mac or even android phone.

See it in action

Inside are an Adafruit Trinked 5V microcontroller board and a cheap rotary encoder. All in all I spend less than 20€ on this project.

Parts I used:

  • Adafruit Trinket 5V, 8MHz
  • 12mm rotary encoder
  • 4mm M2 screw
  • Micro USB cable

Follow the instructions here to wire and program the electronics. Don't worry - it's really basic stuff.

When everything is wired up, the controler acts as an usb input device wich sends out media key commands to your computer.

Have fun printing | soldering | turning | listening | muting

Wiring and board position exposed Alignment

To align the two zylinders perfectly first slide the cap.stl onto the shaft of the rotary encoder. Next apply superglue to the base where the encoder will be placed in the next step.

Now slide the zylinders into eachother and make sure that the gap between the parts is equal all arround. Once the glue dries you're done. Congratulations!

description.text:
When I got my 3mm glass plate for my Anet A6 hotbed I wanted to set the Z endstop a bit higher to compensate. Even if I screwed the bed leveling screws all the way down the glass added too much height and the springs were super compressed. I didn't have my auto-level sensor yet.

I found NickRimmer's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1593629) and printed it immediately. Although it added some height adjustment, I still had to screw the bed down quite a bit, until I noticed that the bump on the design was too short to engage the Z endstop switch at the intended height.

I remixed his design by simply making the bump that hits the Z endstop switch long enough to hit the switch to add the correct amount of height. Now my bed level is raised to allow me to unscrew the bed leveling to a normal amount.

Enjoy!

I wanted a battery bank that could charge or run an IPAD, USB device, laptop, and/or any device for an extended number of charges or for an extended amount of time; I also wanted the versatility of a 12v cigarette adapter. The box had to be small, light, and pack a large number of watt hours. The battery also had to be able to deliver a large number of amps and have a good C rating. The device can be charged from the cigarette adapter and it can run a 19v laptop, or a 24v device with DC to DC converters. The printing and wiring of the device is simple. Lightweight lithium batteries of this caliber are expensive ($150) but SLA batteries are about $20. Care must be taken in connecting the wiring; care must be taken in using the correct charger, you should have the appropriate crimp tool, do not short the battery or confuse polarities. I used a screw and bolt as a terminal block for positive and negative, the screw connects to spade connectors. Spade connectors are included with the 12v car adapter, voltage meter, and usb converter. I used Silicone insulated 12 gauge wire (because I had spare wire); but the components are only rated for 5 amps; thus I could have used a much lesser gauge of wire. I use the same battery for other purposes and I want to support the maximum amperage possible for that battery. Please check the chart that talks about amps, distance, and voltage. CARE MUST BE TAKEN NOT TO SHORT THE BATTERY; ESPECIALLY WITH LIPO. K2 lists Caution warnings on the battery to which you must adhere to and be cognizant of.

Battery - Expensive

K2 12.8V LiFePO4 Battery Pack 9.6Ahr
K2 Energy K2C12V4A 12V 4Ah LiFePO4 Charger with Faston 250 Connectors
Replace Faston with BATTERY TENDER CIG CIGARETTE ADAPTOR check for amperage

This is team 6581-S's mascot robot. Equipped with flag holder (standoff).
Sorry the constraining for the treads was really hard so I had to have stuff clipping through each other to get out the representation.

If you want to get a better tread, go into the assembly (Mousebot.iam) and delete the treads there. Print that and then print 42 tank tread traction links.
I can't do anything about the cortex clipping at the bottom, it had hardly anything I could constrain, by all means edit its constrains and try to fix it. If you want to build a working Mousebot you would probably have to use a real motor and cortex (and battery), so you would need to go into the assembly to delete them. Or use Vex Parts.

Credit for this robot: Thomas, Bryan, Julia

Link to Vex 3D Parts: http://curriculum.vexrobotics.com/appendices/appendix-9 (I used Imperial)

comments.text:
Don't do the forcing of the z-threaded-rod into a bearing, what kind ever.
It rather produces wobble instead of fixing it.
The threaded rod is supposed to swing free.
The plain guiding rods are for positioning.
If you force both, it leads to interference.
Why do you think ALL originals have free threaded rods?

After getting tired of holding figs by the base and trying to paint them. I found a nice painting stand by lasivian. Since then, I have had ideas to improve upon it and create a total system. After using the first one of this new design on a few projects and finding it helpful, I feel it is time to share it.

Included is a slightly modified plate that is similar to lasivian's original design, as well as my redesign that changes the base plate to have guides that hold 28mm,32mm and, 40mm bases. You can use tape, poster putty, or rubber bands to hold down figures that are already based. There are holes through the plates to allow for paper clipped figs and bits to be attached to each one. I have not tried it, but believe a total of 40 or 50 figures could be paper clipped to the plates and sprayed on the rack at once. When printing these plates it is highly recommended you do not use supports, this may differ depending upon your 3dprinter.

You will need at least 21 8mmx3mm round magnets

Obviously, make sure to orient all magnets the same on the detail stand and the spraying rack so the base plates can be swapped without fuss.

comments.author: Kingpin6

comments.text: Thanks for the complement, and im glad u like the design. it looks like you got it pretty well down as to how the system works. If your going to be batch spraying your figs try the handle with ten plate 3B's on it. the orange piece in the last image is where the magnets go for it.

comments.text: for a description of the plate differences check out my reply to Lasivian below here.
comments.author: JtStrait72

comments.text: Can you explain what all the small holes on your custom base are for? Thanks!
comments.author: lasivian

comments.text: lasivian sorry for not responding sooner i didnt notice your question untill late last nite. the slots that run under the surface thru the cut outs are there so u can run a paper clip or piece of wire thru each of them, then bend them upwards in the small notches and attach pre-drilled bits (arms, heads, packs, etc) to them. The square cut outs are there so u can cut the wires with a small cutter. Allowing you to keep the piece mounted upon a wire for detailing. The eight holes that run vertically in a line thru the middle on either side of the magnent are there to allow u to attach a figs legs or body to a paper clip, instead of using a rubber band or tape,and then feed the wire thru one hole then back thru another to lock it in place. i was working on a project to add pics to it showing this, but i have had problems with the gw spray i used orange peeling(damn u gw) and have not had time to strip them to redo it and take pics. In the mean time ill throw up a pic or 2 of the plates with clips run thru them to show what i mean, again, sorry i missed your question for so long.
comments.author: lasivian

comments.text: Is that TPU? It looks like Flexion's x60 filament.  I've used it to make gaskets before, and is by far the most flexible filament I've ever used.  It's also one of the most irritatingly painful ones to use, but worth it when it works.  I considered making something similar with the x60, but thought I'd ask you first.
comments.author: malebox

comments.text: SainSmart TPU. I would call it semi flexible. It's hard but still flexes enough to bend without breaking or delaminating and then return to it's original shape. I like it for things like hand grips (I replaced a rubber grip on my outboard motor) and edge or corner clips when I am designing  holders that I want to snap things in and out of. I even used it make adjustable  tie-rod ends for some suspension sensor linkage on a Land Rover. They mount right beside of the tires where they are subject to all kinds of road grime and weather conditions (live in Colorado mountains). They have been on there for 20 months with no problems.
comments.author: malebox

comments.text: Wonderful!  I use SainSmart TPU myself.  So far, it's been the easiest to work with.  The x60 is unique in that it's basically printed rubber.  Because of that, prints have to be super simple to hold up correctly.  I may try it on these wheels next time I'm feeling patient lol.
